quotes.text: But one thing I am not bound to do, and it is in fact impossible—remain in a life so wretched and so dishonoured any longer than your necessities, or some well-grounded hope, shall demand.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: Sorrow is the beginning and end, sorrow that punishment is most severe when our conduct has been most unexceptionable.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: For happy though but ill, for ill not worst.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: For the untroubled recollection of a past sorrow has a charm of its own.
quotes.author: Cicero
quotes.source: On the Nature of the Gods

quotes.text: The doubtful and varied fortunes of a man, frequently of eminent character, involve feelings of wonder, suspense, joy, sorrow, hope, fear: if these fortunes are crowned with a glorious death, the imagination is satisfied with the most fascinating delight which reading can give.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: Take care, if you love me, to keep your health, lest I should take advantage of your being laid up to eat you out of house and home.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: Now is the time for you to convince us that you are able to bear bad fortune equally well, and that it does not appear to you to be a heavier burden than you ought to think it. I would not have this to be the only one of all the virtues that you do not possess.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: For I think it a disgrace that I should not bear my loss as you—a man of such wisdom—think it should be borne.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: But make haste, in God's name! You know the importance of seizing the right moment, and of rapidity.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: Maintain a political controversy only so far as you can convince your fellow citizens of its justice: never offer violence to parent or fatherland.
quotes.author: Cicero

quotes.text: Virtue is that perfect good which is the complement of a happy life; the only immortal thing that belongs to mortality—it is the knowledge of good and evil.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: The humanity and excellence of clemency is confessed at all hands... for it is of all dispositions the most peaceable and quiet. He that has revenge in his power, and does not use it, is the great man.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Death is the test of life, and it is that only which discovers what we are, and distinguishes betwixt ostentation and virtue.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: It is the bounty of nature that we live; but of philosophy that we live well, which is in truth a greater benefit than life itself.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: No man is born wise; but wisdom and virtue require a tutor, though we can easily learn to be vicious without a master.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: Philosophy is the health of the mind; let us look to that health first, and in the second place to that of the body, which may be had upon easier terms.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: More than we use is more than we need, and only a burden to the bearer.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: The man that would be truly rich must not increase his fortune, but retrench his appetites: for riches are not only superfluous, but mean, and little more to the possessor than to the looker-on.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: The life which is unexamined is not worth living.
quotes.author: Socrates

quotes.text: Nature loves to hide.
quotes.author: Heraclitus

quotes.text: The obstacle is the way.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Knowing others is intelligence; knowing yourself is true wisdom.
quotes.author: Laozi

quotes.text: Truth is what works in the way of belief.
quotes.author: William James

quotes.text: Science is the belief in the ignorance of experts.
quotes.author: Richard Feynman
quotes.source: The Pleasure of Finding Things Out

quotes.text: The whole is more than the sum of its parts.
quotes.author: Aristotle

quotes.text: Do not be too hasty in your judgment of men and things.
quotes.author: Seneca

quotes.text: The sage puts the world away, and so he is always at one with the world.
quotes.author: Laozi

quotes.text: We are doomed to be free; because once thrown into the world, he is forced to choose.
quotes.author: Jean-Paul Sartre

quotes.text: Short is the life of every man; and thine is almost spent; spent, not honouring thyself, but seeking thy happiness in the souls of other men. The time that remains to honour thyself will not be long.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Remember also that every man lives only this present moment, which is a fleeting instant: the rest of time is either spent or quite unknown. Short is the time which each of us has to live.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Order not your life as though you had ten thousand years to live. Fate hangs over you. While you live, while yet you may, be good.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Time is a river, a violent torrent of things coming into being. Each one, as soon as it has appeared, is swept away: it is succeeded by another which is swept away in its turn.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: All things are for a day, both what remembers and what is remembered.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: The present moment is all of which either is deprived, since that is all he has. No man can be robbed of that which he has not.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: The duration of man's life is but an instant; his substance is fleeting. The life of the body is but a river, and the life of the soul a misty dream.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: Man must consider, not only that each day part of his life is spent, and that less and less remains to him, but also that, even if he live longer, it is very uncertain whether his intelligence will suffice as heretofore.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: All things are small, changeable, and fleeting. All the present is but an instant in eternity.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius

quotes.text: You are presently to die, and yet you have not attained to simplicity or calm. The time is at hand when you shall forget all things, and when all shall forget you.
quotes.author: Marcus Aurelius
